passages.text: Deep Dive into Capital Aequacy and Provision Risk Under Cir14; D/G BID to Hold

The IRB shift brings both relief and risk for the Vietnam banks. Based on our simulation, TCB gains the most capital relief, VCB faces minimal profit impact given high coverage, BID is worse off with limited IRB benefit, MBB gains capital headroom but weak provisioning leaves P&L exposed while ACB is resilient though not immune from potential P&L pressure. We cut BID to HOLD and maintain BUYs on others.

Regulatory Transition. Vietnam is moving from the Standardised Approach to the Internal Ratings- Based framework under Cir 14, effective Sep- 2025 and fully phased in by 2030. This new regime introduces stricter minimum capital requirements (CET- 1- 4.5%, Tier- 1- 6%, CAR≥8%), plus capital conservation and potential countercyclical buffers. Importantly, it links dividend payouts to capital compliance and recalibrates risk weights, lowering RWAs for secured lending like mortgages and SMEs but increasing them for higher- risk exposures such as real estate projects. This transition creates both opportunities (capital relief for banks with high- quality secured portfolios) and challenges (provisioning pressure under IRB expected loss calibrations).
Impact on Capital Adequacy. The IRB shift significantly reshapes CET- 1 ratios across banks. Our test scenario highlights:

- TCB gains the most relief, with CET-1 rising above 20% even after the output floor, thanks to its large mortgage book.- VCB strengthens meaningfully (CET-1 base 15.3% vs 11.4% SA), retaining comfortable buffers across all scenarios.- ACB's CET-1 improves to 16.5% base (12.3% SA) and under adverse scenario, 13.7%- MBB lifts to 15.6% base (10.1% SA), though weaker provisioning constrains resilience.- BID stands out as the laggard, with CET-1 ratios only 7.4% base and 6.2% adverse, gaining little from IRB transition.
Provisioning adequacy and P&L risk. Cir 14 also mandates that provisions meet IRB- calculated expected loss. Our stress test shows:

- VCB is exceptionally well provisioned, with coverage >200%, implying very low risk of a profit drag from additional required provisioning.- TCB sit just above 100%, creating some shortfall under harsh assumptions but strong capital buffers means it is unlikely to hit the P&L.- BID rises ~130% coverage under mild assumptions but faces a harsh-case shortfall, exposing P&L risk.- MBB (92%) and ACB (78%) show weaker coverage, suggesting the need to top-up provisions in the coming years. IRB capital buffers help to an extent, but both still face elevated profit risks if there's a push for stricter provisioning alignment.

Earnings and PT changes. We bake in higher provisions over FY2025- 27, cutting earnings for BID (1- 9%), MBB (4%) and ACB (7- 9%, also from lower NIMs). We raise VCB's profit by 1- 7% as it can smooth down provisions without compromising capital position. TCB's earnings are unchanged given ample reserves, with any shortfall absorbable via capital. Our quantum of EPS change differs from profit due to stock and cash dividend assumptions. We roll forward valuations for all five banks: TP rises for VCB, TCB, MBB and ACB, while BID is cut (earnings downgrades and removal of cash dividend assumption). We downgrade BID to HOLD.

Several regulatory changes have been announced in 2025 but we see Circular 14 and Circular 23 as the ones potentially having the most significant impact on Vietnamese banks.

Circular 14/2025/TT- NHNN was issued in mid- 2025 by the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) to replace Circular 41/2016/TT- NHNN. This aligns Vietnam's banking system more closely with international Basel III standards, reinforcing systemic resilience against financial shocks. Circular 14 takes effect from 15- Sep- 2025 and will be fully mandated by 1- Jan- 2030.
Key highlights include:
Stricter capital ratios: banks must maintain a Common equity tier- 1 (CET1) ratio of \(\geq 4.5\%\) Tier- 1 ratio of \(\geq 6\%\) and Total capital adequacy ratio (CAR) of \(\geq 8\%\)

Circular 14 also introduces a capital conservation buffer (CCB), phased in gradually from \(0.625\%\) in year 1 to \(2.5\%\) by year 4 and beyond. A potential countercyclical capital buffer (CCyB) of \(0.2 - 5\%\) might also be applied at SBV's discretion.

Crucially, dividend distributions are tied to capital adequacy compliance. Banks will only be permitted to distribute cash dividends if they maintain sufficient ratios including CCB buffers (CET1, Tier 1 and CAR) above regulatory thresholds.

For example, CAR must effectively reach \(8.625\%\) in the first year of adoption, \(9.25\%\) in year 2, \(9.875\%\) in year 3 and \(10.5\%\) by year 4 prior to payouts. In our view, this approach incentivises long- term stability and aligns payout policies with prudent capital management, particularly for state- owned banks (SOBs) and institutions with thinner buffers.

- Revised risk-weighted assets (RWA) calculation framework: more granular and differentiated risk weights to encourage capital allocation into priority sectors while limiting risks in overheated sectors. Notable adjustments include lower risk weights for lending to SMEs, social housing and agricultural loans, as well as stricter treatment (up to \(200\%\) risk weight) for speculative real estate projects.- Introduction of the Internal Ratings-Based (IRB) approach: qualified banks might adopt IRB models for RWA calculation. While the transition to IRB will require robust data infrastructure and regulatory approval, it signals a decisive shift towards a more resilient and risk-sensitive Vietnamese banking sector.

While Circular 14 targets long- term capital stability, Circular 23/2025/TT- NHNN, issued in Aug- 25 and takes effect from 1- Oct- 2025, amends provisions within Circular 30/2019/TT- NHNN on required reserves. The primary focus lies in a \(50\%\) reduction in the required reserve ratio (RRR) for two bank categories: 1) "assisting" credit institutions under clause 39, article 4 of the Law on Credit Institutions and 2) those undertaking mandatory transfers of distressed banks. Among the banks we cover, Vietcombank (VCB) and Military Bank (MBB) stand to benefit as the measure frees up meaningful capital to expand lending headroom and ease funding pressure.

To recap, VCB took over CBBank (now known as VCBNeo), MBB absorbed Ocean Bank (now MBV), HDB acquired DongA Bank (now Vikki Bank) and VPB took on GPBank. The new regulation allows the four banks to halve RRR from \(3.0\%\) to \(1.5\%\) for deposits under 12 months and from \(1.0\%\) to \(0.5\%\) for deposits of \(\geq 12\) months.

The transition from the current Standardised Approach (SA) for credit risk to IRB is a key element of Circular 14. This affects RWA calculations, thus influencing capital ratios. Below we outline our methodology in assessing this transition and the estimated capital impact on banks under coverage:
We use publicly disclosed 2024 data from the banks which includes:
Reported capital ratios (Tier 1, Total CAR) Total RWAs Loan book segmentation by asset class (eg corporate, retail, SME, mortgage)
CET- 1 is not typically disclosed thus for simplicity purposes we assume Tier \(1 = \text{CET - 1}\) as AT- 1 instruments are negligible in Vietnam.

The current framework requires applying fixed regulatory risk weights depending on borrower type and external ratings. Our baseline case is therefore directly aligned with the bank's published SA capital ratios and RWAs.

Meanwhile the IRB approach allows banks to replace fixed regulatory risk weights with bankspecific parameters such as Probability of Default (PD), Loss Given Default (LGD) and Exposure at Default (EAD). For our simulation exercise:
1) We align the loan book segmentation disclosed by the banks with Basel IRB categories.
2) For each category, in the absence of bank-disclosed PD/LGD parameters, we use benchmark IRB RW% ranges based on Basel formulas and peer Pillar 3 disclosures.

Below are the key risk weights outlined for different exposure classes derived from Circular 41, issued by SBV which implements the Basel II standardised approach vs benchmark IRB RW% ranges based on Basel formulas and peer Pillar 3 disclosures.
Exhibit 4 - Summary of key Rw by SBV and typical IRB risk-weight ranges by exposure

Exposure classKey RW under Basel IIRange of IRB RW under Basel IIISovereigns &amp; Central Banks0% for domestic sovereign, 0-150% for foreign0-20%BanksTypically 20-150% depending on ratings or unrated20-70%Corporates (Large)100% if unrated, 20-150% based on rating40-150%SME90%30-150%Retail - Unsecured75%40-75%Retail - Mortgages35% (LTV&lt;80%), 50-100% otherwise10-30%Retail - Other75%30-100%Specialised lending&gt;160%70-250%
Source: SBV, Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, European Banking Authority, OSFI, HKMA, Jefferies
In our assessment, we have made adjustments to some risk weights to account for Vietnamese credit profiles, wherever deemed necessary.
We run three scenarios to capture a range of possible calibrations:

Base: Mid- point assumptions aligned with Basel IRB curves Optimistic: More aggressive RWA relief which benefits high- quality secured lending portfolios Adverse: Stress assumptions with higher PDs/LGDs

For each scenario, new RWAs are calculated by applying IRB weights to the segmented loan book. CET- 1 capital is held constant while we recalculate CET- 1, Tier 1 and CAR ratios on the IRB- adjusted RWA base. We then apply the Basel III output floor (72.5%) which limits how much capital relief a bank can get by switching from SA to IRB by ensuring IRB RWAs do not fall below the prescribed proportion of SA RWAs.

Vietcombank (VCB)Under the SA, VCB's CAR is \(12.2\%\) and Tier 1 ratio is \(11.4\%\) , supported by VND195,305bn of Tier 1 capital against VND1,712,946bn of RWAs. Credit risk accounts for \(\sim 90\%\) of total RWAs.
Source: Company, Jefferies

We map VCB's loan book into IRB buckets and assign risk- weights under the three scenarios. Based on the prescribed risk weights applied to each loan exposure within the relevant IRB bucket, we derive the adjusted credit RWAs under three scenarios (Optimistic, Base, Adverse). These recalculated credit RWAs are then combined with market and operational RWAs (kept constant at 2024 reported SA numbers) to arrive at the total RWA for each scenario.
Exhibit 7-VCB's loan book by IRB bucket and risk weight

Using VCB's published Tier 1 capital of VND195,305bn (assumed equivalent to CET- 1), we compute the resulting CET- 1 ratios. The results are presented below both on a raw basis (no output floor) and with Basel's \(72.5\%\) output floor applied. As highlighted earlier, the output floor is a key regulatory safeguard, ensuring that total RWAs under IRB cannot fall below \(72.5\%\) of the SA benchmark.

In the Base case, CET- 1 ratio lifts significantly from \(11.4\%\) (SA) to \(15.3\%\) . Optimistic scenario looks even stronger at \(17.6\%\) , but this is before applying the regulatory floor. Even in the adverse case, CET- 1 stays above \(12.9\%\) , comfortably above regulatory minimum.
Exhibit 8-Impact on CET-1 under IRB, no output floor

Source: Jefferies estimates

The floor binds only in the Optimistic scenario, trimming the CET- 1 ratio from \(17.6\%\) to \(15.7\%\) . In the Base and Adverse scenarios, IRB RWAs are already above the floor. This shows that mortgage and prime corporate relief cannot fully flow through, given Basel rules on the minimum denominator.

TCB's loan book breakdown was reclassified recently by combining SME and Corporate under CIBG. We have mapped it by firstly, splitting Retail (Others) portfolio into secured (auto, deposit- backed, collateralised) and unsecured (credit cards and personal loans). Within the corporate and institutional loans, we broke them down into SME, Corporate and Real Estate project financing. The split between SME and Corporate is based on historical proportion (before reclassification took place). Then, we carve out real estate lending from Corporate based on TCB's reported exposure to this sector. This is important as TCB has a practice of financing real estate projects on a ring- fenced, project- by- project basis, where repayment is expected primarily from the cashflows of the underlying development. Under IRB, such exposure falls under Specialised Lending with risk weights ranging from \(70 - 250\%\) .

Having assessed the direct impact of IRB adoption on capital ratios, it is equally important to recognise that provisions and expected loss (EL) calibration under Basel III are a second channel through which capital can be affected.

Under Circular 14, if a bank's accounting provisions fall short of IRB- calculated EL, the shortfall is deducted from CET- 1, immediately reducing regulatory capital. In practice, this also implies a future hit to the P&L as banks will need to increase loan loss provisions to close the gap.

In a fully- developed IRB framework, banks calculate EL at a granular level, with typical parameters ranging from 0.2- 0.5% of exposure for mortgages, 0.5- 1.0% for corporates, 1.5- 2.0% for SMEs and 3- 5% for unsecured retail loans. However, given data limitations in Vietnam and the transitional nature of Circular 14, we have used a simplified benchmark for our sensitivity analysis.

We adopt a \(1\%\) EL factor as a mild calibration and a \(2\%\) EL factor as a harsh calibration and stress test provisions against it. In our view, this range is a reasonable proxy for Vietnam's portfolio mix, where strong collaterals lowers risks in mortgages but higher exposure to SMEs and consumer credit pushes up the blended average.

- Mild calibration: \(\mathrm{PD} = 2.5\% , \mathrm{LGD} = 40\% ; \mathrm{EL} = 1.0\%\) of gross loans- Harsh calibration: \(\mathrm{PD} = 4.0\% , \mathrm{LGD} = 50\% ; \mathrm{EL} = 2.0\%\) of gross loans

We then compare the IRB EL vs current provisions. Any shortfall suggests that potential additional provisions need to be booked over the next few years before Circular 14 is fully implemented by 1- Jan- 2030.
Exhibit 30 - Stress-testing provisions against IRB ECL calibrations
Source: Company, Jefferies estimates

Under the mild calibration, all banks appeared to be provisioned above EL. This means CET- 1 ratios are unaffected and thus there is limited impact on P&L as provision expense should stay relatively stable.

Under a harsh calibration, all banks except for VCB result in shortfalls. To meet EL alignment, these banks may need to raise provisions by VND3,000- 5,000bn each, which could potentially weigh on profits in the next few years. However, the actual treatment of these EL shortfalls largely lies on each bank's capital strength and supervisory pressure. As we alluded to earlier, the shortfall can be deducted from CET- 1 (capital impact rather than accounting charge), but banks which are already thinner- capitalised, the deduction may not be approved by SBV and thus raising provisions would likely be an obvious move.
We summarise below how Circular 14's EL could affect capital the bank's capital position vs profitability:

VCB - Stands out as exceptionally well provisioned, with a coverage ratio of \(>200\%\) and reserves far exceeding Basel- calculated EL under both mild and harsh assumptions. This means no capital deduction is required under IRB and no immediate need to raise provisions through the P&L. In fact, the bank could even smooth provisions down over time without compromising capital strength. As a result, VCB is effectively over- reserved and remains the best insulated among peers, with capital ratios well protected against Circular 14 implementation.

BID - BID carries adequate but not excessive reserves, with a coverage ratio of around \(130\%\) . Under mild IRB calibration provisions appear sufficient, but harsher assumptions points to a potential shortfall of \(\sim \text{VND} 3\text{trn}\) . Given its thinner CET- 1 buffer, this gap would weigh more heavily on capital, and supervisory pressure could translate into higher provision expense over the next 2- 3 years.

TCB - TCB has a coverage ratio just above \(100\%\) , suggesting sufficient reserves against current NPLs but with little headroom. Under strict IRB calibration, a potential shortfall of about VND4trn emerges. However, with CET- 1 ratios comfortably above \(20\%\) under IRB, TCB can easily absorb this through capital deduction without raising provisions immediately. This suggests limited near- term P&L risk.

MBB - MBB's coverage ratio sits below \(100\%\) , the weakest among the larger banks after ACB. While current provisions exceed EL under mild assumptions, harsher IRB calibrations shows a shortfall of nearly VND4tr. With a CET- 1 ratio in the low- teens, MBB has less room to absorb this through capital alone, making it more likely that higher provisioning will be required. This implies both a potential capital deduction and a P&L hit in the coming years, particularly given MBB's SME- heavy loan book.

ACB - ACB has the lowest reserve cushion, with coverage at just \(78\%\) . However the bank points to the fact that \(\sim 95\%\) of its loans are secured, which under Basel IRB should translate into lower LGDs and therefore lower EL. On this basis, provisions would appear ample with some headroom against mild IRB assumptions. However, if the SBV applies conservative LGD floors - particularly on SME loans backed by property - EL rises above current reserves, leading to a shortfall of nearly VND5tr under harsher calibration. While CET- 1 ratios of around \(14\%\) provide some protection, the thin coverage ratio suggests supervisory pressure could still force higher provisioning. For ACB, the reliance on collateral offers comfort, but it does not fully offset the risk of increased provision expense in the coming years.
Exhibit 31 - NPL coverage ratios (2024)
Source: Companies, Jefferies estimates

We raise 2025- 27 profit estimates by \(1 - 7\%\) . We see room for VCB to further smooth down provisions in the next few years without compromising its capital position, given current superior coverage. On top of that, the surplus coverage coupled with strong IRB buffer should make way for the bank to start paying cash dividends and thus we have baked in a \(20 - 25\%\) dividend payout ratio from 2026F onwards. We also roll- forward valuation by one year and our TP is lifted to VND80,504 (from VND69,884).

We cut 2025- 27 profit estimates by \(1 - 9\%\) . We raise our estimates for loan loss provision in the next few years to account for the potential shortfall as the bank transitions to IRB. We also lowered our credit growth assumptions due to capital constraint. We also roll- forward valuation by one year and our TP is cut to VND38,091. Given the \(10\%\) potential downside to our revised TP, we downgrade the stock to a Hold.

We made no changes to our profit estimates for TCB as we believe it has sufficient reserves against current NPLs and even under harsher conditions, the shortfall can be easily absorbed through capital deduction (it will see one of the strongest capital relief from IRB transition) without the need to raise provisions. Our PT, however, is raised marginally to VND47,746 (from VND45,987) as we roll forward valuation. This implies a fair PB multiple of 1.8x on the back of a long- term average ROE target of \(17.9\%\) .

We cut 2026- 27 profit estimates by \(4\%\) each as we bake in higher loan loss provisions. With a CET- 1 ratio in the low- teens, MBB has less room to absorb this through capital alone, in our view, thus necessitating higher provisioning. We roll forward our valuation thus TP is raised marginally to VND36,023 (from VND34,490).

We cut 2025- 27 profit estimates by \(7 - 9\%\) also baking in higher LLP estimates given its low reserves cushion. In addition, we tweaked our NIM assumption downwards as the bank diversifies into lower yielding corporate segment. We expect cash dividends to be maintained albeit at a lower DPS of VND500 (per par value) from 2027F onwards. We roll forward our valuation and our TP rises to VND32,819 (from VND29,834).

ACB is the first bank in Vietnam to issue a dedicated report on ESG. In early 2024, ACB officially launched the 'Green/Social Credit' package with a budget of VND2,000bn. As of Q3 2024, ACB doubled it to VND4,000bn and by the end of 2024, the Bank has disbursed \(84\%\) of the package, equivalent to VND3,363bn.
The Bank has achieved several targets across all three pillars in 2024, which include but are not limited to:

1) Environment: \(93\%\) of ACB staffs committed to practising ESG 
2) Social: 5 consecutive years voted by HR Asia as the best place to work in Asia 
3) Governance: top 50 best listed companies in Vietnam and top 3 listed companies with the Best IR Activities in 2024
These indicators remain ACB's focus within the next five years for the Bank to continue improving on.

- Sharp NPL recoveries 
- Strong economic growth momentum which will have a positive impact on ACB's higher proportion of retail lending 
- Recovery in banca activities 
- Ability to lift CASA ratio to industry level Negative: 
- Lower margins from its shift away from retail into more corporate lending 
- Further tightening of regulations in banca business 
- Weak consumer sentiment which would hamper ACB's growth in the retail and SME lending space

We like VCB for its superior asset quality and strong CASA franchise. Despite having a large asset base, VCB enjoys strong ROEs. As a stateowned bank, VCB has the advantage of having a stable source of low cost funding, but it also participates in the government's requests for interest rate reduction policies to support the economy. As the economy recovers strongly and reduces the need for these supportive policies, we expect VCB's NIMs to improve sharply. The stock's 2.2x 2025 PB is higher than industry average but well justified by its high quality book, in our view.

Vietcombank has been focusing on growing its green credit balance over the years. As of 1Q24, green credits at Vietcombank amounted to VND47.7tr (3.7% of the Bank's total outstanding loans), with \(84\%\) accounted for by renewable energy and clean energy project financing. The Bank also signed credit contracts worth USD200mn and USD300mn in 2019 and 2023, respectively, with the Japan Bank for International Cooperation to finance green and renewables projects. Previously, Vietcombank actively supported the Ministry of Finance as a sub- borrower for the World Bank's Renewable Energy Development project and industrial Energy Efficiency project.

These collaborative efforts, alongside other achievements, helped Vietcombank rank among Top 20 sustainable listed companies in the Vietnam Sustainability Index (VNSI) list for two consecutive years 2023 and 2024. Vietcombank aims to become a leading ESG- focused bank by implementing its Environmental and Social Management System and Environmental and Social Risk Management System in accordance with the VNSI and international ESG standards.

BIDV is one of the pioneering banks in the sustainable development journey, evident through a number of achievements over the years. BIDV maintains its leading position in the field of green finance to have successfully issued VND5.5tr of green bonds and sustainable bonds and developed a Sustainable Loan Framework by international standards. As of 2024, the Bank had the largest green credit balance in Vietnam of over VND75tr (nearly \(12\%\) of the total Green credit balance in the system).

BIDV's goal of becoming a Green Bank is repeatedly highlighted in its "business strategy for the period 2021- 2025 with a vision to 2030." The Bank will focus on researching and implementing the "Green Branch and Transaction Office Model" given the need to promote green credit growth and ESG risk management in credit extension. In 2024, BIDV would introduce new green credit programs, such as mid- long term credit packages in the Central Highlands or the Mekong Delta for crop development, and continue to attract more green foreign capital from international sponsors to Vietnam.

Military Bank set out its 2022- 2026 strategy and led its sustainable development direction in alignment with the economic, social and environmental goals. In 2023, the Bank committed to six key tasks in their ESG framework, including

Asia Commercial Bank (ACB), established in 1993, stands as one of Vietnam's foremost joint stock commercial banks and is the fourth- largest private lender by market capitalization. ACB was first listed on the Hanoi Stock Exchange in 2006 and later the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange in 2020. The Ho Chi Minh City- headquartered bank offers a wide array of financial products and services with 384 transaction offices and more than 13,000 employees across 49 out of 63 provinces. In 2023, ACB was the best- in- class for profitability in terms of return on equity. Besides the traditional banking activities, ACB's operations also encompass four key subsidiaries: 1) ACB Securities (ACBS) 2) ACB Asset Management (ACBA) focusing on trading in distressed asset management 3) ACB Leasing (ACBL), a financial leasing company, and 4) fund manager ACB Capital (ACBC).

Joint Stock Commercial Bank for Investment and Development of Vietnam (BIDV), established in 1957, is one of Vietnam's four state- owned commercial banks. Listed on the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange in 2014, BIDV provides a comprehensive suite of services including traditional and non- traditional banking needs. BIDV held the highest value of total assets and customer deposits in 2023. The Bank has the second- largest network of over 1,000 branches nationwide with more than 26,000 employees. BIDV also has a strong presence abroad with Representative offices in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Taiwan, and Russia. Its key subsidiaries are BIDV Insurance (BIC), BIDV Securities (BSC) and wholly owned BIDV Asset Management (BAMC), each specializing in non- life insurance, securities, and asset management services, respectively. Other subsidiaries and affiliates involve life insurance products, financial and aircraft leasing services and overseas joint venture banks.

Established in 1994, Military Commercial Joint Stock Bank ("Military Bank") is a distinctive player in the banking industry, renowned for its close ties to the military and defense sector. Military Bank's ownership structure includes significant stakes of over \(35\%\) held by state- owned enterprises and military companies, reflecting its unique background and strategic direction of the Central Military Commission - Ministry of Defense, the State Bank of Vietnam, and other military entities. With the parent bank in Vietnam and over 300 local transaction offices, Military Bank has expanded its presence overseas to Laos, Russia, and Cambodia. On top of the traditional activities of a commercial bank, including retail and wholesale banking, Military Bank has diversified its services and products via seven member companies in the fields of investment banking, insurance, and other financial services. The list includes MB Capital, MB Securities (MBS), MBCambodia (a wholly owned commercial bank in Cambodia), Military Insurance (MIC), MB Ageas Life Insurance (MBAL), wholly owned MB Assets Management (MBAMC) and its consumer finance business MB Shinsei Finance (MCredit).

Vietnam Technological & Commercial Joint Stock Bank ("Techcombank") is one of the largest joint stock commercial banks in Vietnam by market capitalization. Founded in 1993, the Hanoi- headquartered bank successfully delivered Southeast Asia's third- largest initial public offering in 2018. Techcombank prides itself in leveraging technology to deliver cutting- edge banking solutions to more than 13 million clients across a network of over 300 transaction offices nationwide. The Bank offers a diverse range of services in the core banking services, such as commercial banking, wealth management and non- financial services, such as real estate. Techcombank also operates through its subsidiaries, including 1) Techcom Securities (TCBS), which specializes in investment banking and securities services 2) its investment management firm Techcom Capital (TCC) with over VND3tn AUM across seven funds by the end of 2023 and 3) Techcombank Asset Management (AMC), an asset manager focusing on portfolio optimization via strategic asset allocation and active management.

Founded in 1963, Joint Stock Commercial Bank for Foreign Trade of Vietnam ("Vietcombank") is one of the leading state- controlled commercial banks in Vietnam. Being the first state commercial bank chosen for pilot privatization by the Government, Vietcombank officially came into operation in June 2008 after the successful implementation of the equitation plan through an initial public offering. Vietcombank is currently listed on the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange and is the largest bank in Vietnam based on market capitalization. Vietcombank has operations across both financial services such as commercial banking, investment banking etc., as well as non- financial services such as real estate. It currently has around 23,700 employees and has over 600 branches across 63 provinces and cities in Vietnam as well as footprints overseas with Representative offices in the US, Singapore and a wholly owned subsidiary in Laos.

We value ACB using both residual income model (65% weight) and fair PB valuation (35% weight). The fair PB multiple that we derive from ACB is 1.7x assuming a long- term average ROE of 19.4%, cost of equity of 13.1% and sustainable growth rate of 4.5%. Key risks to our Buy call and PT

of VND32,819: (1) Sharper than expected NIM compression from lower asset yield and higher funding cost, (2) Spike in retail NPLs as the macro environment weakens and exacerbate on consumer confidence, (3) Structurally lower NIM going forward as ACB diversifies its product mix.

We value BIDV using both residual income model (65% weight) and fair PB valuation (35% weight). The fair PB multiple that we derive from BIDV is 1.4x assuming a long- term average ROE of 16.0%, cost of equity of 12.9% and sustainable growth rate of 4.5%. Key risks to our Buy call and PT of VND38,091: 1) Regulatory changes with more stringent criteria surrounding capital adequacy, 2) Rising credit costs as the economy weakens, posing risk of higher potential defaults.

We value MBB using both residual income model (65% weight) and fair PB valuation (35% weight). The fair PB multiple that we derive from MBB is 1.7x assuming a long- term average ROE of 19.0%, cost of equity of 13.3% and sustainable growth rate of 4.5%. Key risks to our Buy call and PT of VND36,023: 1) Deterioration in asset quality as MBB takes on higher risks with the higher credit quota. Its consumer finance arm may also be susceptible to higher NPLs if the economy slows down, 2) Stiff competition from other banks to grow their retail market share, 3) Increased credit and capital risk from struggling bank takeovers.

We value TCB using both a residual income model (65% weight) and fair PB valuation (35% weight). The fair PB multiple that we derive from TCB is 1.8x assuming a long- term average ROE of 17.9%, cost of equity of 12.2% and sustainable growth rate of 4.5%. Key risks to our Buy call and PT of VND47,746: (1) Disappointing recovery in real estate market leading to slower credit growth and higher credit cost, (2) Further NIM pressure from rising competition particularly in retail lending, (3) Spike in NPLs as the macro environment weakens.

We value VCB using both residual income model (65% weight) and fair PB valuation (35% weight). The fair PB multiple that we derive from VCB is 2.2x assuming a long- term average ROE of 19.2%, cost of equity of 11.1% and sustainable growth rate of 4.5%. Key risks to our Buy call and PT of VND80,504: 1) Intense competition leading to margin compression, 2) Rising credit costs as the economy weakens and pose risks of higher potential defaults, 3) Increased credit and capital risk from struggling bank takeovers.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of 15% or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus 15% or minus 10% within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus 10% or less within a 12- month period.

The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(is 20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) \ \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\$ the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
